official-title.#text: To authorize the Director of the National Institutes of Health to design and enter into agreements for the implementation of prize competitions with the goal of improving health outcomes and thereby reducing Federal expenditures.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Part B of title IV of the Public Health Service Act

header.#text: Prize competitions for improving health outcomes and reducing Federal expenditures

text.#text: The goal of the prize competitions under this section is to improve health outcomes, thereby reducing Federal expenditures on health programs.

short-title.#text: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Congressional Budget Office

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and relevant health economists, shall identify 3 to 5 human diseases or health conditions with respect to which—

text.#text: Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of the
the Federal Government, for such diseases and conditions, collectively spends a total of not less than $5,000,000,000 per year on prevention and treatment activities;

public and private investment in research is disproportionately small in comparison with such investment for other human diseases and conditions for which the Federal Government has similar or greater expenditures on prevention and treatment activities; and
the prize competitions under this section would be appropriate for achieving the goal described in subsection (a).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014

text.#text: Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of the
design prize competitions—
to cooperate with competitors to realize innovations to achieve the goal described in subsection (a) with respect to one or more diseases or conditions identified pursuant to subsection (b); and
to award one or more prizes—
if appropriate, at the beginning of or during the competitions, to the competitors whose innovations are most promising or demonstrate progress; and
at the end of the competitions, to the competitors whose innovations prove to be the best solutions;
ensure that the design of such competitions—
is realistic, given the amount of funds to be awarded as prizes;
does not reflect any bias concerning the type of innovations which will prove to be the best solutions;
allows any person to participate as a competitor without regard to the person’s place of incorporation, primary place of business, citizenship, and residency, as applicable; and
addresses areas of unmet need with regard to a lack of recent and pending innovations; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the design of such competitions.

In carrying out paragraphs (1) and (2), the
medical, economic, budgetary, innovation, and venture capital experts; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the National Science Foundation
Administrator of the Small Business Administration

text.#text: the heads of relevant Federal agencies, including the
The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014

text.#text: not later than 14 months after the date of enactment of the

to perform a simulation of the prize competitions to be conducted under this section, based on the designs developed under subsection (b)(2) and in consultation with the categories of experts and agency heads described in subsection (b)(3); and
to use the simulation to assess the effectiveness of the design; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the results of the simulation and assessment.

text.#text: not later than 4 months after awarding such one or more contracts, submit to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014

text.#text: Not later than 21 months after the date of enactment of the

taking into consideration the results of the simulation under subsection (c), and subject to the requirements of subparagraphs (A) and (B) of subsection (b)(2), make such adjustments to the design of the prize competitions under this section as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on any such adjustments.

text.#text: submit to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall enter into an agreement with one or more private entities to implement prize competitions based on the designs developed under subsection (b)(2), as adjusted under subsection (d).

text.#text: The
The prize competitions under paragraph (1) shall require competitors to demonstrate the effectiveness of their innovations over a period of not more than 5 years.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may cooperate with qualified competitors in the prize competitions under paragraph (1) by providing guidance and access to testing facilities.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Guidance and access to testing facilities

text.#text: The
a total of not more than 5 prize competitions under this section; and
not more than 2 such prize competitions with respect to any disease or condition.
The
collect information on—
the medical efficacy of innovations funded through the prize competitions under subsection (e); and
the actual and potential effect of the innovations on Federal expenditures; and

not later than one year after the conclusion of the prize competitions under subsection (e), and not later than the end of each of the 4 succeeding years, submit to the Congress a report on the information collected under paragraph (1).
The Federal Government may not gain an interest in intellectual property developed by a participant in a prize competition under subsection (e) without the written consent of the participant.

header.#text: Prohibition on the government acquiring intellectual property rights

text.#text: The Federal Government may negotiate a license for the use of intellectual property developed by a participant in a prize competition under subsection (e).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , there are authorized to be appropriated

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}prop.#tail: , in lieu of amounts authorized to be appropriated by

text.#text: Of the total assistance awarded to private entities under subsection (e) (including in-kind contributions and testing or other technical support) to implement any prize competition under this section—
not more than 30 percent of such assistance shall be for administration of the prize competition; and
not less than 70 percent of such assistance shall be awarded as prizes to competitors in the prize competition.

header.#text: Prizes excluded from gross income of recipients

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (as in effect immediately after the enactment of this subsection).
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 409K of the Public Health Service Act

text.#text: Gross income shall not include the value of any prize received by the taxpayer pursuant to a prize competition under

header.#text: Certain prizes for improving health outcomes

text.#text: The amendment made by this subsection shall apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act.
